fields.description:
I have no idea why, but this has been happening for way too long now, at least since one version before 2.4, maybe since Sierra came out.

I launch SourceTree and it starts to reopen the repos I had open last time, usually just 2 or 3 tabs, but then it just crashes. I think every time it crashes when I reopen it, it doesn't crash again, at least not that I remember, so it's just the first time I try to open it. Its there any info that I can send you that could be useful to you to track this problem down? Thanks!

*manolo*
fields.summary: Crashing on launch
Commit template is not displaying under Preferences

fields.description:
The Bitbucket repo was working ok with Sourcetree, until I upgraded it to version 2.4
Now I get this error when trying to pull or push:
{code:java}
ssh: Could not resolve hostname bitbucket.org:***: nodename nor servname provided, or not known
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
{code}
A github repo I have still works ok with Sourcetree.
fields.summary: After updating to 2.4, I lost access to a bitbucket.org repo. Github working ok.

fields.description: There is an menu option Window->Merge All Windows which merges the repo windows into a single tabbed window (like the Windows interface). But there's not way to *always* do that. I keep having to click that option (there isn't even a shortcut for it).
fields.summary: Add 'Always Merge Windows' option

fields.description:
After upgrading to 2.4 (96) the "unstaged files" view disappeared. Both unstaged and staged files are in the same view. Tried to restart SourceTree but the issue remains

I don't know how to replicate this. It just happened the first time I opened the new version.
fields.summary: "Unstaged files" view gone

fields.description:
Hey guys!

Many teams have code styles these days and my team have it too. There is a rule in our code style "Max length for a commit message is 70 symbols".

It's not convenient to type a commit message in SourceTree with the limit for length now. I have to enter text in a text editor with symbol counter, then copy-paste into the commit textbox in SourceTree.

Please add the counter (see TortoiseGit as an example).

Thanks,

Maxim
fields.summary: Add a symbol counter for commit message

fields.description: Please add a dark mode
fields.summary: Add Dark Mode

fields.description: Sourcetree to uncheck "Store Password in Keychain" by default, numerous login attempts requires to uncheck them each time.
fields.summary: Uncheck Keychain password box by default

fields.description: Would love to have a dark skin on SourceTree. More and more people use dark theme these days, and it would be nice if my favourite git client matched.
fields.summary: Dark skin

fields.description:
It would be great if I could expand a remote, select multiple branches and delete them.

 

I like to keep a github fork of my company's repos.  The problem is that forking brings all branches into my account and I do not want them.  It would save time to remove all, or almost all branches from a remote.

 

Example implementations

[https://coderwall.com/p/eis0ba/remove-a-thousand-stale-remote-branches-on-git]

[https://gist.github.com/schacon/942899]
fields.summary: Remove multiple remote branches
Add preference to turn off spell correction in commit messages

fields.description: Upon pushing changes to a branch, I'm asked by MacOS to allow or deny access to the keychain. I press always allow each time, then after one of two of those prompts, I'm asked for my password. I enter the password, then I'm told that I was denied permission to push the changes. When I check the branch in bitbucket, the changes have been pushed.
fields.summary: Being asked to enter credentials at every push to a branch

fields.description:
I used it all the time in GitX (rowanj). The proposed shortcut is ⌥⌘A, but anything would do the job.

 

Thanks!

Elia
fields.summary: Add a keyboard shortcut to amend commits

fields.description:
Consider the following scenario:
 * Pull dev (main) branch.
 * Create a branch thereof (say release-xyz)
 * Now go to Remotes -> origin and check out another branch (let's call it feature_one)
 * Checkout release-xyz again
 * Try to merge feature_one into release-xyz
 ** => Expectation: branch feature_one is the list of candidates in the merge's dropdown list
 ** => Actual: the branch is misssing. Only restarting SourceTree will make feature_one appear in the branch list in the merge dialogue.
fields.summary: Branch list doesn't refresh for merge to include freshly checked-out branches.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

User is adding their Bitbucket account in SourceTree via OAuth and with SSH authentication.
Afterwards, the following error shows up, when viewing the {{Remote}} tab in SourceTree:   !Screen Shot 2017-01-23 at 10.34.31.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Environment

SourceTree ver 2.4 (90), maxOS Sierra 10.12.3 Beta (16D25a)

h3. Steps to Reproduce

We haven't been able to reproduce this issue. A user has reported that it occurs when:
# They remove all entries from {{Keychain Access}} related to {{bitbucket.org}}
# They add their Bitbucket account in SourceTree with OAuth (and SSH authentication).
The user has tried to add their account both from SourceTree {{Preferences}} >> tab {{Accounts}}, and also from SourceTree's repo browser >> gear >> {{Accounts..}}.
# When the account is added, the error mentioned above appears
(Check screen recording in comment -- and additionally logs)

h3. Expected Results
The account is added successfully

h3. Actual Results

After the account is added, the following error appears:  !Screen Shot 2017-01-23 at 10.34.31.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Adding an account via OAuth is failing in some cases

fields.description: Click the "Convert to https" in the main screen menu ( where all the repositories are shown). The ones that are already https, get "https://" appended at the beginning of the path, making the path not functional.
fields.summary: "Convert to https" feature pre-appends "https" to already https remote paths

fields.description: Notifications appearing when changes are detected in a repository should use the bookmark's full "path" in the SourceTree bookmarks (for example, instead of "lib1", it should be "proj/wiki/lib1", to distinguish it from "proj/src/lib1")
fields.summary: Notifications should use the bookmark's full name

fields.description:
I have two accounts in github. I found I cannot save them both as OAuth, so I save one as OAuth, one as basic. I use ssh for OAuth account, https and password for basic account.

Every time when I commit to basic account, source tree will ask for the github password. Even I select "save to keychain", it still ask me next time. The account page have password saved already, and I can refresh remote repo in the basic account without need of inputing password.

I checked keychain in my mac, it only have the OAuth login saved, no 2nd github login found. So it seemed that sourcetree didn't save the login to keychain successfully.
fields.summary: Keep asking github every time even selected "save to keychain"

fields.description:
Customer report:

{quote}
Our project has complex tree of subrepos. It works without a lag in command line and in other clients.

But SourceTree every action takes about 5-15 seconds to perform, during which client freezes completely. Every click. This was gradually degrading with each version of SourceTree for a while now.

Please. Make option to ignore subrepos.
{quote}

Upon downloading 2.4e:

{quote}
While initial impression was very nice, I realized that it is still extremely slow. UI doesn't lock when refresh is done, but I timed it.
* Source Tree Refresh takes about 12 seconds
* `hg diff` takes 0.2 second
* `hg diff -S` takes 0.3 second

`hg diff --git -S` takes 0.3 second too.
{quote}
fields.summary: Incredibly Slow with mercurial subrepos

fields.description:
Please watch my short video illustrating the experience.   
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wPUAkG78BFE&feature=youtu.be

 

Scenario 1:

On MacOS X Sierra when setting up SourceTree for first time and choosing "SSH" as the authentication method, SourceTree:
 #  Should not have a URL for the Bitbucket server, should be a hostname without the https://
 # Should not need a "password"
 # Generate SSH Key button is greyed out
 # User can skip setup and perform this step manually through the Remote Repository Browser's "Add Account" function

Scenario 2

On MacOS X Sierra when using the "Add Account" function the experience when selecting SSH as the authentication method is:
 # URL is asked for, should be a hostname
 # Password is not needed
 # User should be able to select an existing ssh key on their system
 # Generate Key button is visible and clickable, when clicked, process continues, but no key is generated and a "Tooltip" is displayed when account is saved indicating no SSH key
 # When editing the account, and selecting "Generate Key" it now works (but generates a public/private key with a "space" in the filename (e.g. mwilde_Bitbucket Server.pub)

After putting my public key in my account on Bitbucket and trying to clone, errors are related to what is in the ".ssh/config" file this occurs.
 # No hostname is in the ".ssh/config" file (edited by SourceTree) causing a failure on clone 
 # When hostname is added, errors occur due to "space" in filename
 # When ".ssh/config" is edited removing spaces and subsequently renaming the private key to match the reference in the ".ssh/config" file

After "fixing" all of these issues, cloning only works thru the CLI, or via a "Clone in SourceTree" link up in Bitbucket Server.   Cloning does not work through the remote repository browser.

Please watch my short video illustrating the experience.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wPUAkG78BFE&feature=youtu.be   

Note:  I have a few hundred people in my company i'd like to train on SourceTree (and have them use SSH keys if possible), so please fix this ASAP.
fields.summary: Generating SSH Keys is broken (using Bitbucket Server) -- ui and config file
Add the abilitu to sort repositories into 'Project folders'

fields.description:
*Bug:*

With Bitbucket and github account setup correctly and everything works, if mac os reboot sourcetree will fail to connect. Error "public key denied".

Through SourceTree itself there is no way to fix this error unless user delete the public key and generate new one, add new key again.

*Diret Cause:*

The identity is not loaded into ssh agent.

{{ssh-add -l}} return empty. Once the keys were added, everything works.

*Root Cause:*

macOS/OS X till Yosemite used to remember SSH keys added by command {{ssh-add -K <key>}}.

Unfortunately this way no longer works and command {{ssh-add -K}} in macOS Sierra no longer saves SSH keys in OS's keychain. As Apple Developer stated: _"That’s expected. We re-aligned our behavior with the mainstream OpenSSH in this area."_

[this|http://superuser.com/a/1155833] and [this|https://github.com/jirsbek/SSH-keys-in-macOS-Sierra-keychain]

SoureTree created config file in .ssh folder and added some entries. However this didn't work.

It's also possible there are something in security setting of my mac which prevent it work. I tried ssh-add -K which seemed add them to keychain, but ssh-add -A reported that "No identity found in the keychain."

Right now my bandit remedy is to run a script to add the identities manually after every reboot or logout.
fields.summary: identity isn't loaded into SSH Agent after reboot or logout for mac os Sierra

fields.description: Source Tree will crash when attempting to Clone if you manage to click on "Clone" before Source Tree has discovered whether it is a Git or Mercurial repository. See attached images for screenshots of the UI element in question.
fields.summary: Source Tree crashes when attempting to Clone before discovering repo type.

fields.description:
SourceTree for Mac had a shell injection vulnerability starting with 1.9.8 prior to 2.3.1 (the fixed version). By visiting a malicious website or by convincing a user to click a sourcetree:// URL with a vulnerable version of SourceTree for Mac installed an attacker could use a shell injection vulnerability to execute arbitrary commands on a victims machine.

 

*Affected versions:*
 * All versions of SourceTree for Mac from 1.9.8 before 2.3.1 (the fixed version) are affected by this vulnerability. 

h4. *Fix:*
 * *SourceTree for Mac version 2.3.2 is available for download from [https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/?v=mac.|https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/?v=mac]*

 

*Acknowledgements:*

We would like to credit *Matthew Diaz* of NCC Group Security Advisory for reporting this issue to us.
fields.summary: Shell Injection in SourceTree for Mac

fields.description: The new GUI-right click option "Copy Branch Name to Clipboard" should be moved to the bottom of the list, as it is not so important and often used like the other menu options. The first one should be "Checkout [branchname]" because it is the most used one.
fields.summary: Move "Copy Branch Name to Clipboard"-right click option to bottom of list
SourceTree crash in 2.4 version
HTTPS authentication is failing with OAuth

fields.description:
h2. Feature Request

Add a menu item "Show Repository Browser" to the Dock Menu of SourceTree for Mac
h2. Reason

I have many repositories (and corresponding bookmarks). Assume the following scenario: I have opened some repositories, but their windows are minimized. I now would like to open another repository using the Repository Browser. To achieve that, I have to perform the following steps at the moment: (1) click on the SourceTree icon, which shows one of the minimized windows, (2) pressing "Cmd + 0", (3) minimizing the "wrong" window again, and finally (4) open the repository I was looking for using the Repository Browser. If the Dock Menu would contain an item "Show Repository Browser", I could easily achieve the same result without having to perform the steps (1) and (3). Would make life much easier!

 

Thank you for considering this request.
fields.summary: Repository Browser in Dock Menu

fields.description:
I see 2 buttons:
 * Use an existing account
 ** It opens a modal in-app browser, showing my Atlassian profile on the web. I can click save in the browser view, log in, or log out. But no way to proceed. Below the browser viewport is a cancel button that closes the modal. Now what? Why am I seeing my profile? What’s the point?
 * Go to my Atlassian
 ** It opens my browser, I see my licenses – now what? Why am I here?
fields.summary: Can’t proceed past the Atlassian Account step

fields.description:
With 2.4 we added an option to have  SourceTree manage your SSH key per account - it generates the key and optionally adds to your SSH configuration. The warning just indicates when that isn't present. We did not detect existing SSH configurations and map them to accounts you've set up in ST.

Existing/configured SSH users should simply ignore the feature essentially, just set the protocol to SSH and continue on past the error message.  *However, users should not be receiving the error message on a regular basis, which they are currently with 2.4.*
fields.summary: SSH key warning popup should be disabled once it has been viewed.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
 # Make sure that you have some staged files and you're on the *"File status"* workspace.
 # Select the last one.
 # Click, drag, release fast a few times (3 - 10 times).
 # SourceTree crashes.
fields.summary: Crash when fast dragging staged files
Add the abilitu to sort repositories into 'Project folders'

fields.description:
When clicking on a modified file and trying to see the differences, SourceTree scroll the Diff section up repeatedly when it refreshes Git or something (the refresh icon is turning).

 

This is quite an issue on a bigger code base where refresh takes some time. It is very common that I click a file, scroll the differences down, ale it scrolls up, and then I again scroll down and it scrolls up again, etc.

 

This is very annoying behavior, especially when the file I am looking at did not change and still SourceTree refreshes the diff section as well.

 

It would be nice if SourceTree either does not refresh the diff content, or better remember the scroll position and scroll to it upon diff section refresh.
fields.summary: File diff scrolls up constantly

fields.description: The diff view seems to be blurry when scrolling horizontally on SourceTree 2.3.2.
fields.summary: Blurry diff view when scrolling horizontally

fields.description:
As a user, when I'm entering a commit message, I would like to adhere to the 50/72 rule so that my commits are consistent with the team and general Git guidelines.

*GIVEN* I am committing a file to a repository, *WHEN* I enter the message into the commit textview, *THEN* I would like to see the *line* and *column* of the cursor's current position *AND* these values should change appropriately as I edit the commit message.

For example, you could put a label underneath the commit message textview that contained *Line:Column*. I would expect the values to change as I type so that they values always reflect the current location of the cursor. This would be especially helpful given that the commit message textview uses a variable width font.

Technically, it is the Column value I would find most valuable as it is the message width that is harder to estimate quickly.

[http://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html]

[https://medium.com/@preslavrachev/what-s-with-the-50-72-rule-8a906f61f09c#.beztdl16t]

[http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2290016/git-commit-messages-50-72-formatting]

Thanks,

-Luther
fields.summary: Line:Column label when creating a Commit message.

fields.description:
{quote}I appreciate that SourceTree is just a front end for git (or mercurial), but what I was hoping for/am imagining is a config option to use a different diff tool.

For example, the most common solution for diff/merge of utf 16 that I run across on the web is to use vimdiff as described in the solution here:

[http://stackoverflow.com/questions/777949/can-i-make-git-recognize-a-utf-16-file-as-text]

If SourceTree does not already have an option to use a different diff tool, I suppose I am requesting that a configuration be added to SourceTree to use a different diff tool.
{quote}
fields.summary: Supports diff and merge on UTF-16 text files

fields.description:
Cannot get past "Atlassian account" screen in welcome wizard.

 

Clicking "Use an existing account" takes me to the "Manage your account" screen (I'm already authenticated). Clicking "Go to My Atlassian" takes me to the license management part of the site (I'm already authenticated).

 

I've tried clicking things that look like next steps. Tried force-quitting the app and restarting. No way of getting through.

 

This was a great app, but now I literally cannot get in and use it, which has brought my workflow to a grinding halt!
fields.summary: Cannot get through authentication screen

fields.description:
Ever since I upgraded to 2.3.2, clicking the "Stage Hunk" or "Stage Lines" buttons in the Hunk Browser (or whatever it's called) cause it to scroll to the top of the file. This makes staging individual hunks of a file utterly nightmarish, since I have to scroll back down past all the hunks I didn't want to stage _each time I stage a new hunk_.

The previous version of Source Tree I had been using didn't have this problem. The hunk browser would stay at the same location within the file whenever I staged an individual hunk.

Please fix this ASAP, as it makes using SourceTree extremely frustrating.
fields.summary: Staging lines or hunks causes the hunk browser to scroll to the top

fields.description:
When a commit is selected, I no longer see the file list for the changed files in the commit (expected on the left side of the lower panel below the commit information). Attached are two screenshots of the same repository, selecting the same commit, but changing the display options for the files changes which one is selected, therefore what diff is seen to the right.

I thought maybe it's hidden and can be dragged up from the bottom, but that only shows the Command History.

This is happening in all my repositories.

This makes SourceTree unusable as I cannot see the full content of previous commits.
fields.summary: File list is missing when examining a commit

fields.description: In a git commit message, it is typical to have a shorter first line as a subject, and longer lines after. Some systems enforce this convention. A single column guide when writing a commit message is not sufficient to meet these requirements without manual counting or guess-work.
fields.summary: There should be an option for two column guides in the commit message

fields.description:
After update of the mac SourceTree client I cannot get past the login window for the Atlassian account.

The new client requires me to log in, I pressed "Use an exiting account", log in with my credentials but I have no option to continue. The only button I can press is cancel even though I'm logged in. Now I cannot use the client at all!
fields.summary: Updated client, cannot get past login window

fields.description:
I'm running on macOS sierra and recently updated to sourcetree 2.4.
But I'm constantly getting authentication issues with pretty much all actions when I connect to my repository on bitbucket.
The error (and often the message is output multiple times) is:
remote: Invalid username or password. If you log in via a third party service you must ensure you have an account password set in your account profile.
fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://username@bitbucket.org/repositoryname/repo.git/'
I've retried many times and it seems to be a bit intermittent.
I've tried restarting sourcetree and the whole machine.
I've also changed from basic to Oauth and back - no difference.
Operations do seem to succeed but it is very hard to tell because SourceTree 'says' there are errors.
Some operations definitely succeed, so the password is definitely correct.
I also use Webstorm and the VCS integration there works without error to the same repo.
fields.summary: Authentication issues after updating to sourcetree 2.4 (87)

fields.description:
After some intensive use of 'hg evolve' (I think), I'm not getting the following error when refreshing the SourceTree History view:

'hg log' failed with code 255:'abort: hidden revision '331993'!
(use --hidden to access hidden revisions)'

It would be great if SourceTree could handle these hidden revisions. Or alternatively give me a way to automatically taylor hg commands that you use, so I could add '--hidden' myself.

 

And I don't know if it's related, but I can only see 6 days of history, the bottom one below 331068 saying 'Error, see log'; clicking on it shows:

'hg status' failed with code 255:'hg: parse error at 11: invalid token'

fields.description:
When using the "Stage hunk" button to stage changes for git, the diff view each time scrolls to the top. This is very annoying if I want to say, stage hunks 10 to 15 out of 20, as for each hunk I stage, I next have to scroll back where I was, stage the next hunk, and so on.

Note that sometimes, when I wait a moment longer after staging the hunk, the diff view flickers as if it was scrolled back to the top and redrawn *again* ...

This used to work flawlessly, but at some point in the past broke (unfortunately, I do not know whether it correlated with a SourceTree update).

I already have the "Refresh automatically when files change" option disabled in the preferences, as that also used to cause things to scroll at arbitrary times. But it is almost as if staging a hunk now ignores this setting... ?!?

 

This is *really* annoying, as it negatively impacts my usual workflow quite seriously. For now, I am back to using "git add -p", but I'd really prefer to use SourceTree for this again, as it also allows me to quickly stage or discared individual lines.
fields.summary: Staging hunk causes diff view to scoll to top

fields.description:
*Summary:*

SourceTree should respect ALL .gitmodules settings.

Right now it only seems to respect url and path.

The most critical setting (IMO) is submodule.<name>.ignore as specified in documentation at [https://git-scm.com/docs/gitmodules]

*Reasoning:*

Build process may create/modify files in a submodule, however this does not mean changes should be tracked (in case submodule used for build).

*Expected behavior:*

SourceTree respects "ignore = dirty" and "ignore = all" settings of .gitmodules

*Actual behavior:*

SourceTree ignores these settings and prompts "Uncommitted submodules" dialog every time. Very annoying.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not respect "ignore" of ".gitmodules"

fields.description:
More git hosting services are popping up all the time, some of which have an API (e.g. Unfuddle, Codebasehq.com), and also many people self-host on gitweb, cgit and potentially others. We can probably never keep up with every service explicitly, so it would be nice to have a way for the user to plug in some kind of hook to support whatever API they wanted, so that their projects will appear on the Hosted Projects view (of course, any hosting service at all can still be used regardless just by using the clone/remote URL).

Probably don't want to make this a native plugin, because that's trickier for people to write and also might have security issues. Ideally some kind of scripting hook might be best. Don't want to add a whole scripting engine to SourceTree just for this, maybe we can repurpose AppleScript, Python or even just call out to a shell script of the user's choice.
fields.summary: Pluggable API options for Hosted Projects

fields.description:
On version 2.4, diff settings allows changing the Size limit for text and binary. Nonetheless, the bottleneck currently seems to be on the number of Hunks.

When there is a commit with a big amount of hunks (>100) SourceTree usually hangs, regardless of the file sizes and that is very annoying.

UI text size option

fields.description:
Having multiple parallel graphs (in our case supported release versions), we often need to track down where a branch branched off from another one and then go through the commits since this branching point. Tracing back is somewhat feasible using the "Parents: ..." links in the commit details view. However, there is no way to go "back up" i.e. "back to the previously selected commit".

I think for this and many other scenarios, it would be helpful if SourceTree would store a history of selected commits, similar to a browser's history of visited websites for each tab. Just like in a browser, I envision "go back" and "go forward" buttons in the top button menu which would allow to jump back and forth between the previous commit selections (and gray out if one reaches either end of the history stack). If the user previously selected multiple commits, this multi-selection should probably be restored as well.

Just like we already have "Parents: ..." links for each commit, it may also be helpful to have "Children: ..." links for each commit. However, for our use-cases, the browser like "go back" and "go forward" buttons would be more helpful.
fields.summary: "go back" / "go forward" in History view

fields.description:
I cloned a remote repository from the "Remote" tab and instead of the `origin` URL being "git@bitbucket.org/myaccount/repository-name.git" it was "ssh://git@bitbucket.org/myaccount/repository-name.git". When trying to remove the "ssh://" part, I got the following error when trying to fetch or pull:
{quote}git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree fetch --tags --prune origin

fatal: 'git@bitbucket.org/myaccount/repository-name.git' does not appear to be a git repository

fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights and the repository exists.

Completed with errors, see above
{quote}
None of my other Bitbucket repositories are requiring the "ssh://" part in their remotes, and all of those are working fine. This only appears to affect repositories from Bitbucket - GitHub remotes are all fine.
fields.summary: Some repositories require "ssh://" part in their remote's url, where most do not

fields.description: Recently I am seeing this issue again. The message is wrong as you do not need to restart the machine just the application. I suspect that this is something entirely separate. This typically occurs if you have many repo open (40 in my case) and SourceTree running for a long time (over a day). The bug reference you are pointing to offer a solution but also I would suggest that you allocate NSPipe too aggressively, it take some time for the autorelease pool to do its work and you probably allocation too many too quickly.

fields.description:
After answering No to the "Do you want to move this app to the Applications folder?" alert that pops up on launch (when SourceTree is not in the Applications folder), the UI is in a slightly messed up state. The file list view won't redraw its selection after being clicked, and it doesn't take keyboard focus.

Workaround is to either answer Yes, or check the "Do not show this again" checkbox, then quit and relaunch. I.e. if this alert doesn't come up at launch time, the problem does not appear.

(Note: I experienced this with a custom dev build of 2.4; have not reproduce with the released 2.3.2.)

Steps To Reproduce
 # Quit SourceTree while a repo window is open
 # Either move SourceTree out of /Applications, or launch another copy that's somewhere else (in my case, I was testing a downloaded custom build in my Downloads folder.)
 # Launch SourceTree
 # "Do you want to move this app to the Applications folder?" alert appears
 # Press "Don't move" (or "No" or whatever the negative choice is.)
 # The repo window appears but is not highlighted as active; it may be hidden behind windows of other apps. If necessary click the SourceTree icon in the Dock.
 # Go to history view
 # Select a commit with multiple files changed
 # Click different files in the file list pane
 # NOTE: The file list doesn't update; it still shows the first file selected (in gray)
 # Press up/down arrow keys
 # NOTE: Selection does not move nor does the diff pane change
 # Quit SourceTree
 # Relaunch SourceTree
 # In the "Move this app" alert, check "Do not show this again", then press "Don't Move".
 # Quit SourceTree
 # Relaunch SourceTree
 # Repeat steps 7-12 to verify that the bug is gone
fields.summary: "Do you want to move this app?" alert messes up file list display

fields.description:
A typo like "cuberoot" for "cube root" should not be ignored.

A space was introduced in a file, replacing the one word "cuberoot" by two
words "cube root". With "Ignore whitespace" set, the change was not shown
in SourceTree. It was, of course, visible when "Show whitespace" was
selected.

It looks to me as though SourceTree is using the git diff option -w:

-w, --ignore-all-space
Ignore whitespace when comparing lines. This ignores differences
even if one
line has whitespace where the other line has none.

rather than -b:

-b, --ignore-space-change
Ignore changes in amount of whitespace. This ignores whitespace
at line end,
and considers all other sequences of one or more whitespace
characters to be
equivalent.
fields.summary: Ignoring whitespace could be smarter

But SourceTree can't detect this, and is still showing number badge on PUSH button.

git push for reference

fields.description:
Hello,

I recently generated a new pair of keys to be used with my Yubikey for SSH logins. I successfully added the ssh public key to Bitbucket and it is correctly installed on my system (ie visible from ssh-add).

When I use the git command line everything works fine: for every remote git command to Bitbucket (even from a terminal launched from Sourcetree), macOS asks me the pin to properly unlock my Yubikey (where the private key is securely stored) and the git command ends with success.

Unfortunately, when I try the very same remote command through Sourcetree GUI, it fails. From the log I see that Sourcetree\git is trying to directly unlock the private key without asking for the pin (in fact, macOS's pin dialog is never shown).

I suspect this error occurs with every external token card for SSH.
Could you please investigate this issue and make sure that Sourcetree properly works with an external token card?

Thanks for your help.

Best Regards,

Nicholas

References:
[http://florin.myip.org/blog/easy-multifactor-authentication-ssh-using-yubikey-neo-tokens]
[https://www.isi.edu/~calvin/yubikeyssh.htm]

_Note: initially reported to Atalssian Service Desk (code: STSP-5478)._
fields.summary: Sourcetree fails to authenticate to Bitbucket with git and ssh using yubikey

fields.description:
I use a Mercurial server with HTTP authentication and since SourceTree version 2.4 (Mac) pulling from the server fails due to problems with the authentication modules.

Steps to reproduce:
 * In 2.3.x I already had a configuration with a mercurial repository that uses HTTP authentication, which worked fine
 * updated to 2.4
 * tried to pull: clicked Pull
 * the preview window appears that normally would list the new change sets, overlaid with the "Authentication Required" dialog to enter Username/Password
 * entered username/password
 * the "Incoming changes" list stays empty ("No changes to pull")
 * click OK
 * the "Authentication Required" dialog appear again
 * entered username/password
 * the progress info shows "Pulling from default" and then the error output below. The error message begins with "Unknown exception encountered with possibly-broken third-party extension sourcetree_auth which supports versions unknown of Mercurial. Please disable sourcetree_auth and try your action again." (see attachment exception.log for full message)

Then I edited sourcetree_hg_auth.py to fix the variable name erroutput/erroroutput in lines 149 and 170. When I try to pull after this change, there is a different error message: "Error calling askpass for username: 2016-12-12 17:22:19.750 SourceTreeLogin[60365:25486566]" with a crash backtrace in SourceTreeLogin.

I attached that error message as crash.log. 

The main SourceTree app does not crash.
fields.summary: Pull from Mercurial server with HTTP authentication fails in 2.4

Clone a few repositories.

Close sourcetree.

Delete at least 2 of the repositories from disk.

Open sourcetree. The deleted repos are marked "Repository moved or deleted"

Highlight more than one, right-click, and Delete. When prompted to confirm, click OK.

Sourcetree crashes, and the following errors are reported (see attachment)
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes if you attempt to delete more than one repository at a time, that was moved or deleted
iPhone 5 - The "Text words are crossed" on the "Main page" after displaying the portrait orientation
Move Underneath repository label bug

fields.description:
I have two ongoing issues with diff-view in the latest stable SourceTree (2.3.2) for MacOS (10.11.6).

While in the "File Status" workspace, looking at a file diff, while my cursor is in the commit message box (cursor, not mouse pointer), with each blink of the cursor, the horizontal scroll bars on each diff-hunk grow, as if the lines just got longer. But only after I scroll the diff a little bit with my mouse wheel!

Here's a brief video (40mb) of the bug in action: [https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3831772/sourcetree_bug.mov]

Additionally, the diff view seems to refresh itself, resetting vertical scroll position all of the way at the top, a few moments after selecting a file whose diff I want to view. It also does this after you stage a hunk which is INCREDIBLY annoying, because I then have to scroll back down to find where I was before I staged that hunk.
fields.summary: SourceTree diff horizontal scroll bars are wigging out! (Mac)

fields.summary: SourceTree crashed when trying create remote repository

fields.description:
Some views automatically scroll back to their default position frequently, which disrupts my work and makes me loose time scrolling back to where I was. This happens way to often.

For instance:

Commit history view scrolls to the commit/branch that's checked out.

File status->diff views scroll back to the top.

I suppose this happens due to some refresh, probably coming from GIT. It's unacceptable and make SourceTree look cheap and buggy.
